reviewText: The fabulous team of director Emilio Fernández and cinematographer Gabriel Figueroa made with "Enamorada" another great example of Mexican film in its days of glory. They were both central figures in La Epoca de Oro of Mexican filmmaking, as was Fernández' favorite actor, Pedro Armendáriz, who made 14 films for the legendary director in his nearly 3 decade long career, which included 3 films for John Ford, and the 1963 James Bond "From Russia With Love", which was to be his last; here he plays a revolutionary general, and he is handsome, funny, and very moving in the part.Maria Félix was one of the most exquisite creatures to walk the earth, and was Mexico's biggest star; she is perfect as the beautiful Beatriz, a woman who is strong enough to melt the general's heart while giving him a slap and a punch. Félix also had a long lasting career, which spanned from the early '40s through 1970.The plot for "Enamorada" has similarities to "The Taming of the Shrew", and is a romance set in the turbulent times of 1821, that has much drama as well as some hilarious scenes (my favorite is when Beatriz finds out her mother was "stolen"). Lovely music enhances the film, with Shubert's "Ave Maria" and Pedro Galindo's "La Malagueña".Others in the cast that are excellent include Fernando Fernández as Padre Sierra, José Morcillo as Beatriz' father, and Eugenio Rossi as her fiancée."Enamorada" was a huge success, and won many Ariel Awards (Mexico's Oscar), including Best Picture, Actress, Director, Screenplay, and Cinematography, with Armendáriz winning a special Outstanding Career Ariel. The film was remade in Hollywood with the same Fernández/Figueroa/Armendáriz team as "The Torch" in 1950, but with Paulette Goddard in the female lead; it was no match to its predecessor and was a dismal failure. Other Golden Age cinematic treasures from this trio include "Flor Silvestre" ('43), "Maria Candelaria" ('44), "La Perla" ('47), and "Maclovia" ('48), which also starred Félix.There are no subtitles, and total running time is 99 minutes.

reviewText: This is grand movie from Mexico's golden age in cinema. The stars are the beautiful Maria Felix and the handsome Pedro Armendariz, both of whom have an extensive filmography. Maria Felix is erroneously given credit by Amazon as being the director, when in fact it was directed by Emilio Fernandez. In black and white released originally in 1946, it is a classic piece of film. At times the sound is a little distracting as the sound of the reel or some peripheal noise can be heard. The story evolves around the lead actors, Armendariz who is a guerilla general, and Felix as an aristocratic woman. The story takes place in the town of Cholula , Mexico amid colonial architecture. The time period is the Mexican Revolution and the story begins with El General and his men taing over the town and rounding up the wealthiest for the rebel firng squad. After an initial interrogation of various men, as a way of introducing the supporting  cast, the story rolls along. Some mens lives are spared but some are faced with the firing squad. Enter Maria Felix as the daughter of one of the richest men, Don Penafiel. El General is immediately love struck but she is appalled by him and what he represents. From here the movie moves along into a series of funny situations that make the romance difficult, she is not interested. El General softens his tough exterior and makes some consessions in an attempt to win her over. The inevitable end result is no surprise but the process is funny. Maria Felix , who had a way about her for playing the tough woman, is great. What is most memorable about her is the looks she gives with her eyes. When there is no dialogue her eyes are more expressive than any words could transmit to the audience. She has daggers that are incredible projecting from her eyes. In fact, most of the actors in this movie use their eyes to express themselves quite remarkably. This is a good historical piece, lots of humor, little violence(by todays standards), romance, and some meaning to the contradictions and implications of Mexico's war among it's own people. As an old time movie, this one holds your attention for just under 100 minutes. I can still see Maria Felix's eyes, so vibrant and expressive, she is unforgetable.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great classic of Mexico's Golden Age of Cinema in the 1940s by its greatest director, Emilio Fernandez.  Yes, these films are a little syrupy, but so was abuelita's atole; its the Mexican way.  The opening scenes with the cannon going off and the horses galloping in the Revolution are wonderful.  This film stars Maria Felix, the Katherine Hepburn or Elizabeth Taylor of Mexican cinema, as well as Fernandez's regular Pedro Armendariz (see him also in the Bond classic From Russia with Love).Regarding the Cozumel Films DVD: the image is far from the Jeanne d'Arc treatment, but be happy to see this film at all.  Also, there are no subtitles so its for Spanish speakers only.  No extras to speak of, but we can forgive that if Cozumel films hurries along DVD releases of "La Perla", "Maria Candelaria", and most importantly, the 1949 classic "Salon Mexico".

reviewText: This is my parents favourite movie, and I surprised them by hunting it down. They think of this as the signature Armendariz film and my father tears up every time he watches it.

reviewText: Excellent film from our Mexican golden age of cinema. The performance is amazing with Maria Felix and Pedro Armedariz. The story, the landscape, and the photography and the music are beautiful. Don't miss this DVD.NOTICE: A very curious fact. The las scence before the word FIN (END) is so close to that performed by Marlene Dietrich in Marrakech. A necklace broken and a woman who follows her man and left a wedding compromise...There are also an English version of ENAMORADA, nearly with the same actors except María Felix. Such version was made as a request of the main American actress but the result is not the same.

reviewText: (Alter films edition)Of course is not historic, is a romanitc melodrama, have a distant reference with The Taming of the Shrew of Skakespeare. And as you can see in all other reviews on this clasic Mexican picture is highly enjoyable. I love this one and I recomend highly as well Macario and Maria Candelaria. The photography of Gabriel Figueroa is superlative for the time. And warning for English only speakers, the imported to USA Alter films edition have (YES!) English and Spanish subtitles.
